keyTakeAways: Typhoon Halong's remnants caused catastrophic flooding and wind damage in remote Alaskan villages, destroying up to 90% of homes in Kipnuk and affecting over one-third of homes in Kwigillingok.
More than 2,000 people were displaced, with over 575 evacuated by military aircraft to Anchorage and additional evacuees expected.
The federal government is being requested to declare a major disaster, which could provide funding for emergency and permanent repairs, shelter, and long-term housing.
Residents, such as Alexie Stone from Kipnuk, are facing significant lifestyle changes, with many uncertain about returning to their traditional hunting and fishing communities.
Anchorage officials and leaders have pledged support, including shelter provision, emergency supplies, and community integration efforts, emphasizing regional solidarity.

summaryOfNewsArticle: In western Alaska, remnants of Typhoon Halong caused catastrophic flooding and wind damage, destroying up to 90% of homes in Kipnuk and affecting nearly one-third of homes in Kwigillingok. Over 2,000 people were displaced, with more than 575 airlifted to Anchorage by the Alaska National Guard. Governor Mike Dunleavy has requested a major disaster declaration from President Donald Trump to secure federal aid for emergency and long-term recovery. Due to the severity of damage, many residents may not be able to return to their homes for at least 18 months. Anchorage officials, including Mayor Suzanne LaFrance and State Representative Nellie Unangiq Jimmie, have committed to welcoming and supporting evacuees, while individuals like Alexie Stone reflect on the disruption to traditional lifestyles and future uncertainties. The event underscores the vulnerability of remote Alaskan communities to extreme weather and the interdependence of rural and urban regions in disaster response.
title: Remnants of Typhoon Halong Leave Widespread Damage in Alaska Villages, Displacing Over 2,000 People
